posts.cooked:
Signal is great, but Molly IM is even greater: https://molly.im/
App locking, encrypted datatabase, Backup scheduling, Ram shredding, Tor support, open street map support, and a few more of those.

What I am not seeing from Signal is anyone writing a post on why certain features would not work for the masses or else when they will look at implementing them into Signal. All we see is complete silence about Molly.

WHY. Signal, say something.

I can only agree that I am glad Molly-FOSS exists. Being able to use a non-Google notification service that keeps our messaging metadata out of their hands is my favorite feature.

It would be great if Signal could roll in some of those enhancements, but as long as they remain agreeable to options like Molly using their infrastructure, I’m more than happy to keep using Molly.

For other use-cases, everyone in the message chain having more private and secure clients would be very important.

And I dont want to change the topic of your post, but I’m also watching SimpleX for the phone number-free aspect.

Meteor0id:

Signal, say something.

Signal devs are busy enough developing features and fixing bugs, I wouldn’t think they’d (or want them to) take time to sit and write commentary about other forks.

With regards to features and reasons for why this or that isn’t on Signal (yet or never), this has to do with priorities as well as ideology.

For example, DB encryption may be appealing to a certain segment of users (who have indeed found a home in Molly), it’s not applicable to many or most. Plus, Moxie was against it way back when and I guess this ideology has trickled through to current management.

Tor support - we know that using Tor is much safer than using a Signal proxy. However, Signal proxies are “good enough” for most people’s requirements, are simpler to set up in the app for the masses (all they need to do is find a proxy URL and paste it in or just click on a link, as opposed to installing Orbot and playing around with bridges etc if necessary), and Tor may introduce latency etc that Signal support may not want to have to deal with. So again it comes to what is the management’s attitude to risk vs reward with this, and while one can argue “tor is best” and another can argue “Signal proxy is best”, both can be right in their respective threat model.

Signal is working on some features that Molly has, like for example linking an Android device as a linked/secondary device, so it does work the other way round too. Whether Signal had always wanted to include that and just got round to it, or whether they saw it became very popular with Molly, it’s of course impossible to tell

posts.name: Preston Maness
posts.cooked:
What I am not seeing from Signal is anyone writing a post on why certain features would not work for the masses or else when they will look at implementing them into Signal. All we see is complete silence about Molly.

I asked about Tor integration here about a year ago, which was itself a renewed request from three or four years ago. I offered to implement the feature if there was commitment to making it a default at some point in the app. Nobody from the Signal Foundation – devs, ambassadors, leadership – responded. I have queried Meredith – the current President of the foundation – on Mastodon multiple times and fallen on deaf ears.

WHY. Signal, say something.

One possibility is given by @DonDino :

Companies that have a public roadmap have different headaches.
“Why don’t you have X/Y/Z on your roadmap?”
“Missed the deadline again? You said X would be ready last month! You’re so unreliable!”

And so on.

Unpublished roadmap = no headaches.

Though I’d say that an unpublished roadmap merely transfers the headaches from the organization to its users

However, I suspect that the reason Tor support – and other Molly features – aren’t getting pulled in is because the Signal Foundation fears getting leaned on by the United States if they make their product too privacy-friendly. The current arrangement allows sufficiently resourced adversaries to build up a social graph of Signal users, which is a majority of what would interest such adversaries, at least as a first-pass sweep of establishing a collection of targets for further surveillance. Getting at the underlying data would entail breaking the endpoints, a second-pass effort that would be less scalable. And of course, all of this ignores the fact that Signal maintains a list of phone numbers of its users, which would in all probability be the zero-pass sweep such an adversary would take.

There’s also the money concern, of course. Signal, at present, is existentially dependent upon its billionaire benefactor, Brian Acton. Unless Signal has started to raise tens of millions annually from contributions/donations of users, it will likely run out of money by the end of this year or next (unless, of course, Acton decides to inject more cash into the effort or the foundation finds other sources of funding).

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked:
aspensmonster:

There’s also the money concern, of course. Signal, at present, is existentially dependent upon its billionaire benefactor, Brian Acton. Unless Signal has started to raise tens of millions annually from contributions/donations of users, it will likely run out of money by the end of this year or next (unless, of course, Acton decides to inject more cash into the effort or the foundation finds other sources of funding).

The donation part is quite some speculation on your part. Signal is funded 95% (if not higher, now) by user donations at the moment. There’s no indication that they’re relying primarily on Brian Acton at the moment. You can take a look at the most recent 2023 tax report which corroborates this.

The rest of your post is leaning on reasons that point towards conspiracy theory territory. Signal is used worldwide by millions of users, the simplest reason is usually the right one, they aren’t implementing some of these features because there are other higher priority features, and these features usually come with significant headaches for the casual user trying to use them.

Those users that need better protections, already have the necessary knowledge of tools necessary to achieve them, so it’s likely focus should remain mainly on general improvements that can platform wide improve privacy for everyone (ECH support and other advancements). Especially with the current strain on resources.

There’s also the case that Molly is already fulfilling a more niche purpose in this case. Why duplicate efforts? It’s not like Signal is hostile towards Molly. Molly seems to be quite the natural extension IMO.

DonDino:

if airport security sees when their wife was at the supermarket.

This sounds an awful lot like arguments against end-to-end encryption, it’s just the grocery list after all, isn’t it?

Anyway having better at-rest encryption would very beneficial for Signal, considering that forensic companies can unlock almost any Android phone when in after-first-unlock (AFU) state. For example they could mark the database encryption key as unavailable after screen is locked.

This would require rearchitecting the app and keeping some keys as always available so that notification can still be received and decrypted, but would protect against exploits recovering data from locked devices.

The reason they specifically don’t do this (IMHO of course) it that they believe physical access or code execution on the device is always a lost cause (it’s not) and they are more focused on in transit encryption that endpoint security.

posts.name: Preston Maness
posts.cooked:
The donation part is quite some speculation on your part. Signal is funded 95% (if not higher, now) by user donations at the moment. There’s no indication that they’re relying primarily on Brian Acton at the moment. You can take a look at the most recent 2023 tax report which corroborates this.

Does the FY2023 990 corroborate that? The major revenue sources are 22M in contributions (990 - Part VIII - (1f)) – identity of contributor(s) restricted as per Schedule B - Part I – and 10M in program services (990 - Part VIII - (2g)), almost all of which is licensing revenue (990 - Part VIII - (2a)). That’s in the ballpark of the total functional expenses of ~36M (990 - Part IX - (25)). Further, FY2022 990 - Part X - (22) has an end-of-year balance on the loan from Acton of 32M, and FY2023 - Part X - (22) has an end-of-year balance of basically 33M. The balance on the loan has not meaningfully changed. The net assets (FY2023 990 - Part I - (22)) are bottoming out at 3M. That’s not the portrait of a non-profit that is healthy and growing on the back of a large base of contributors.

My hope is that FY2024’s 990 shows a better picture. And of course, nothing prevents the Signal Foundation from going beyond the letter of the law and providing more detailed financial statements that break down, exactly, how much of their revenue is from small-dollar contributors versus larger ones.

The rest of your post is leaning on reasons that point towards conspiracy theory territory.

We’ve known for a decade now (since the Snowden leaks) that the adversaries in question make sophisticated efforts to spy on everything they can. A large e2ee provider like Signal is a very juicy target to such adversaries. And you also concede that other users “need better protections,” so I hardly think this is conspiracy territory.

so it’s likely focus should remain mainly on general improvements that can platform wide improve privacy for everyone

…

There’s also the case that Molly is already fulfilling a more niche purpose in this case. Why duplicate efforts?

There would be no duplication of efforts if Signal were to bring in Molly’s feature set. Molly’s feature set would also definitely “improve privacy for everyone.” Signal, of course, doesn’t have to expand its scope to support these efforts – and indeed has indicated recently that it considers network-layer anonymity to be beyond its scope:

“Signal has never attempted to fully replicate the set of network-layer anonymity features that projects like Wireguard, Tor, and other open-source VPN software can provide”

But I think, given the current political climate in the United States, that Signal should reconsider whether or not such efforts should be in its scope. Ultimately though, they’re a non-profit with no contractual obligations to their user base. They can do as they please.

aspensmonster:

However, I suspect that the reason Tor support – and other Molly features – aren’t getting pulled in is because the Signal Foundation fears getting leaned on by the United States if they make their product too privacy-friendly. The current arrangement allows sufficiently resourced adversaries to build up a social graph of Signal users,

The Tor project admits that a sufficiently advanced adversary can de-anonymize Tor traffic. Sure, Tor analysis is harder to do than just analyzing traffic to Signal’s servers, but Tor doesn’t eliminate the threat. Realistically, anyone who could do this attack on just Signal servers could also do the same for Tor. Or any other VPN.

Tor also isn’t without cost. It increases latency, which is a significant downside for audio and video calls.

Fortunately, you can run all your traffic through a VPN or Tor with standard apps, or you can use Molly for a more targeted approach.

I wouldn’t mind having the option in Signal, but I can understand why the devs consider it lower priority than other work.

As always, everyone has different priorities, and we’re never all going to agree.
